summary: This is the First Amendment and Restatement to the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two, executed on January 27, 2012. It outlines the trust's administration during Epstein's life and the distribution of assets upon his death, including specific bequests to named individuals. The document establishes Darren K. Indyke, Jes Staley, and Andrew Farkas as trustees.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The creator and grantor of the trust, who reserves extensive rights to amend, revoke, and withdraw principal during his lifetime.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: One of the trustees appointed to administer the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two, as per the 2012 amendment.

persons.name: Jes Staley
persons.context: One of the trustees appointed to administer the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two, as per the 2012 amendment.

persons.name: Andrew Farkas
persons.context: One of the trustees appointed to administer the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two, as per the 2012 amendment.

persons.name: Jeffrey A. Schantz
persons.context: Named as a trustee in the original 2001 trust agreement, but not listed as a trustee in this 2012 amendment.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Named to receive a $5,000,000 distribution from the trust upon Epstein's death, if he survives Epstein.

persons.name: Luciano A. Fontanilla, Jr.
persons.context: Named to share a $1,000,000 distribution with Rosalyn V. Fontanilla upon Epstein's death, if they survive him.

persons.name: Rosalyn V. Fontanilla
persons.context: Named to share a $1,000,000 distribution with Luciano A. Fontanilla, Jr. upon Epstein's death, if they survive him.

persons.name: Harry I. Seller
persons.context: Notary public who witnessed and notarized signatures on the trust amendment document.

connections.description: Epstein appointed Indyke as a trustee of his 2001 Trust Two, granting him fiduciary authority over the trust assets.
Epstein appointed Staley as a trustee of his 2001 Trust Two, granting him fiduciary authority over the trust assets.
Epstein appointed Farkas as a trustee of his 2001 Trust Two, granting him fiduciary authority over the trust assets.
Epstein designated Brunel to receive a $5 million bequest from his trust upon his death, indicating a significant financial connection.
Both are named as joint beneficiaries to share a $1 million distribution from Epstein's trust upon his death.
Both serve as co-trustees of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two.
Both serve as co-trustees of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two.

events.title: Original Trust Agreement Established
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein entered into the original Trust Agreement for the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two with himself and Jeffrey A. Schantz as trustees.

events.title: Trust Amendment and Restatement Executed
events.description: Epstein executed the First Amendment and Restatement to the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust Two, appointing new trustees and outlining post-death distributions.

keyFacts: Jeffrey E. Epstein retained extensive control over the trust during his lifetime, including the right to amend, revoke, and withdraw principal at his discretion.
Upon Epstein's death, the trust designated a $5 million bequest to Jean Luc Brunel, a French modeling agent and associate accused of involvement in Epstein's sex trafficking scheme.

The trust appointed Darren K. Indyke (Epstein's longtime lawyer), Jes Staley (former JPMorgan executive), and Andrew Farkas (real estate investor) as trustees in 2012, replacing the original trustee Jeffrey A. Schantz.
The document includes provisions for distributions to other unnamed beneficiaries (redacted in the text) and to staff members Luciano A. Fontanilla, Jr. and Rosalyn V. Fontanilla.
The trust agreement is governed by the laws of the United States Virgin Islands, a jurisdiction known for favorable trust laws.
